column4: I'm trying to get the 32-bit version of Firefox installed on my Ubuntu 64-bit system, and I can only find it as an RPM. Should I use Synaptic to remove my current Firefox version and then install the new Firefox by converting the rpm to a deb and then installing it? Or is this utterly loony?
just update Firefox with synaptic and be done with it
Um....what do you mean? Synaptic gives me 64-bit Firefox...I think....
additionally, Orborde , you might want to delete or move the file libflash-mozplugin.so out of your firefox directory
I don't know if Synaptic gives you a 64 bit version of Firefox, but frankly man, does it bloody matter?
its a web browser Orborde , not a physics simulator
besides, 64bit apps eat more memory space, which is more important with a web browser than OMG WEB PAGE LOADED IN 0.01ms INSTEAD OF 0.015ms
I want Flash to work. It doesn't get along with 64-bit Firefox AFAIK, but I dunno.
what makes you think theres a 64bit flash plugin? *laughs*
ask macromedia if they've compiled a 64bit plugin, or if they'll give you the source to do it...*chuckle*
I know there isn't. But I gather that running 32bit Firefox might work.
in theory.
I've had experience with the bug you're talking about
I did a gdb backtrace
its possible it might still crash/not work with a 32bit Firefox
so, it might be all in vain
additionally, not using synaptic with a distro as heavily modified as Ubuntu, is, unwise, to say the least
if you're sudo'ing or using root, its a good way to kill your Linux install
Okay.
WYSIWYG

if you're that thirsty for Flash, try a different browser to Firefox until the plugin gets fixed, I believe it will get fixed with 5.10/breezy, for now, see if any other browsers support a 64bit flash plugin (opera?)
